sen.j: 松平 春嶽（まつだいら しゅんがく）は、江戸時代後期の大名、第16代越前国福井藩主。
sen.e: Shungaku MATSUDAIRA was a Japanese feudal lord, the 16th lord of the Fukui Domain of Echigo Province in the late Edo period.
Shungaku MATSUDAIRA was a Japanese feudal lord, the 16th lord of the Fukui Domain of Echigo Province in the late Edo period.
Shungaku MATSUDAIRA was a Japanese feudal lord, the 16th lord of the Fukui Domain of Echigo Province in the late Edo period.

sen.j: 明治の政治家である。
sen.e: He was a statesman in the Meiji period.
He was a statesman in the Meiji period.
He was a statesman in the Meiji period.

sen.j: 春嶽は号 (称号)で、慶永（よしなが）が諱である。
sen.e: Shungaku is his second name, and Yoshinaga is his imina (personal name).
Shungaku is his second name, and Yoshinaga is his imina (personal name).
Shungaku is his second name, and Yoshinaga is his imina (personal name).

sen.j: 田安徳川家第3代当主・徳川斉匡の八男。
sen.e: He was the eighth son of Narimasa TOKUGAWA, the third head of the Tayasu-Tokugawa family.
He was the eighth son of Narimasa TOKUGAWA, the third head of the Tayasu-Tokugawa family.
He was the eighth son of Narimasa TOKUGAWA, the third head of the Tayasu-Tokugawa family.

sen.j: 松平斉善の養子。
sen.e: He was adopted to Narisawa MATSUDAIRA.
He was adopted to Narisawa MATSUDAIRA.
He was adopted to Narisawa MATSUDAIRA.

sen.j: 将軍徳川家慶の従兄弟。
sen.e: He was a cousin of Shogun Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA.
He was a cousin of Shogun Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA.
He was a cousin of Shogun Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 英邁な藩主で、四賢侯の一人と謳われた。
sen.e: He was a great domain lord and called one of the four remarkable feudal lords.
He was a great domain lord and called one of the four remarkable feudal lords.
He was a great domain lord and called one of the four remarkable feudal lords.

sen.j: 明治維新後の初期にも重要な役割を果たした。
sen.e: He played an important role in the early days after the Meiji Restoration.
He played an important role in the early days after the Meiji Restoration.
He played an important role in the early days after the Meiji Restoration.

sen.j: 江戸城内の田安邸に生まれる。
sen.e: He was born in the residence of Taoka in the Edo-jo Castle.
He was born in the residence of Taoka in the Edo-jo Castle.
He was born in the residence of Taoka in the Edo-jo Castle.

sen.j: 中根雪江に教育を受け、天保9年（1838年）に斉善が死去すると11歳で藩主となる。
sen.e: He was educated by Yukie NAKANE and then became the head of the domain at the age of 11 after Narisawa died in 1838.
He was educated by Yukie NAKANE and then became the head of the domain at the age of 11 after Narisawa died in 1838.
He was educated by Yukie NAKANE and then became the head of the domain at the age of 11 after Narisawa died in 1838.

sen.j: 同年、元服。
sen.e: The same year, he reached the manhood.
The same year, he reached the manhood.
The same year, he reached the manhood.

sen.j: 将軍徳川家慶の一字を賜り、慶永と名乗る。
sen.e: Receiving one Chinese character of Shogun Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA's name, he took the name of Yoshinaga.
Receiving one Chinese character of Shogun Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA's name, he took the name of Yoshinaga.
Receiving one Chinese character of Shogun Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA's name, he took the name of Yoshinaga.

sen.j: 正四位下、左近衛権少将・越前守に叙任。
sen.e: He received Shoshiinoge (Senior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) and was appointed to Sakone gon no shosho (Provisional Minor Captain of the Left Division of Inner Palace Guards) and Echizen no kuni no kami (Governor of Echizen Province).

He received Shoshiinoge (Senior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) and was appointed to Sakone gon no shosho (Provisional Minor Captain of the Left Division of Inner Palace Guards) and Echizen no kuni no kami (Governor of Echizen Province).

He received Shoshiinoge (Senior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) and was appointed to Sakone gon no shosho (Provisional Minor Captain of the Left Division of Inner Palace Guards) and Echizen no kuni no kami (Governor of Echizen Province).

sen.j: 中根や由利公正、橋本左内らに補佐され、洋楽所の設置や軍制改革などの藩政改革を行う。
sen.e: Supported by Nakane, Kiminasa YURI and Sanai HASHIMOTO, he carried out the reformation of domain duties such as establishing yogakusho (English school) and implementing military system reform.
Supported by Nakane, Kiminasa YURI and Sanai HASHIMOTO, he carried out the reformation of domain duties such as establishing yogakusho (English school) and implementing military system reform.
Supported by Nakane, Kiminasa YURI and Sanai HASHIMOTO, he carried out the reformation of domain duties such as establishing yogakusho (English school) and implementing military system reform.

sen.j: 嘉永4年（1851年）左近衛権中将。
sen.e: He became Sakone gon no chujo (Provisional Middle Captain of the Left Division of Inner Palace Guards) in 1851.
He became Sakone gon no chujo (Provisional Middle Captain of the Left Division of Inner Palace Guards) in 1851.
He became Sakone gon no chujo (Provisional Middle Captain of the Left Division of Inner Palace Guards) in 1851.

sen.j: 嘉永6年（1853年）アメリカのマシュー・ペリー率いる艦隊が来航して通商を求めた際には、水戸徳川家の徳川斉昭や薩摩藩主の島津斉彬とともに海防強化や攘夷を主張するが、老中の阿部正弘らと交流して開国派に転じる。
sen.e: When the American fleets led by Matthew PERRY came to Japan to ask for commerce in 1853, he insisted on reinforcement in marine defense and expulsion of foreigners together with Nariaki TOKUGAWA from the Mito-Tokugawa family and Nariakira SHIMAZU, the lord of the Satsuma Domain, but turned to the open country wing after interaction with Masahiro ABE, Roju (senior councilor of the Tokugawa shogunate).

When the American fleets led by Matthew PERRY came to Japan to ask for commerce in 1853, he insisted on reinforcement in marine defense and expulsion of foreigners together with Nariaki TOKUGAWA from the Mito-Tokugawa family and Nariakira SHIMAZU, the lord of the Satsuma Domain, but turned to the open country wing after interaction with Masahiro ABE, Roju (senior councilor of the Tokugawa shogunate).

When the American fleets led by Matthew PERRY came to Japan to ask for commerce in 1853, he insisted on reinforcement in marine defense and expulsion of foreigners together with Nariaki TOKUGAWA from the Mito-Tokugawa family and Nariakira SHIMAZU, the lord of the Satsuma Domain, but turned to the open country wing after interaction with Masahiro ABE, Roju (senior councilor of the Tokugawa shogunate).

tit.e: Ansei no Taigoku (suppression of extremists by the Shogunate)
Ansei no Taigoku (suppression of extremists by the Shogunate)
Ansei no Taigoku (suppression of extremists by the Shogunate)

sen.j: 13代将軍徳川家定の将軍後継問題では、橋本左内を京都に派遣して運動させ、一橋徳川家当主の一橋慶喜（後の徳川慶喜）を後押しする。
sen.e: For the issue on successor to the 13th Shogun Iesada TOKUGAWA, he sent Sanai HASHIMOTO to conduct a campaign and supported Yoshinobu HITOTSUBASHI (later Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA), the head of Hitotsubashi-Tokugawa family.

For the issue on succession to the 13th Shogun Iesada TOKUGAWA, he sent Sanai HASHIMOTO to conduct a campaign and supported Yoshinobu HITOTSUBASHI (later Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA), the head of Hitotsubashi-Tokugawa family.
sen.cmt: successor をsuccessionに変更しました。
sen.e: For the issue on succession to the 13th Shogun Iesada TOKUGAWA, he sent Sanai HASHIMOTO to conduct a campaign and supported Yoshinobu HITOTSUBASHI (later Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA), the head of Hitotsubashi-Tokugawa family.

sen.j: 幕閣では将軍後継問題で紀州徳川家の徳川慶福（後の徳川家茂）を推す南紀派で彦根藩主の井伊直弼が大老となり、14代将軍後継は慶福に決定する。
sen.e: The cabinet officials of the Shogunate belonged to the Nanki group which recommended Yoshitomi TOKUGAWA from the Kisyu-Tokugawa family (later Iemochi TOKUGAWA) for the shogun successor issue and then Yoshitomi became the successor as the 14th Shogun after the lord of the Hikone domain, Naosuke II became Tairo (chief minister).

The cabinet officials of the Shogunate belonged to the Nanki group, which recommended Yoshitomi TOKUGAWA from the Kisyu-Tokugawa family (later Iemochi TOKUGAWA) for the shogun successor issue and then Yoshitomi became the 14th Shogun after the lord of the Hikone domain, Naosuke II became Tairo (chief minister).
sen.cmt: nanki groupの後にカンマを追加しました。The successor asを削除しました。
sen.e: The cabinet officials of the Shogunate belonged to the Nanki group, which recommended Yoshitomi TOKUGAWA from the Kisyu-Tokugawa family (later Iemochi TOKUGAWA) for the shogun successor issue and then Yoshitomi became the 14th Shogun after the lord of the Hikone domain, Naosuke II became Tairo (chief minister).

sen.j: 幕府が朝廷の勅許無しでアメリカとの日米修好通商条約を調印すると春嶽は徳川斉昭らとともに登城をして抗議し、不時登城の罪を問われて謹慎処分を下された。
sen.e: When the bakufu signed the Treaty of Amity and Commerce between the United States and Japan without permission of the Imperial Court, Shungaku came to the castle with Nariaki TOKUGAWA for protest and was suspended at home for going to the Castle untimely.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: When the bakufu signed the Treaty of Amity and Commerce between the United States and Japan without permission of the Imperial Court, Shungaku came to the castle with Nariaki TOKUGAWA for protest and was suspended at home for going to the Castle untimely.

When the bakufu signed the Treaty of Amity and Commerce between the United States and Japan without permission of the Imperial Court, Shungaku came to the castle with Nariaki TOKUGAWA for protest and was suspended at home for going to the Castle untimely.

sen.j: また左内は処刑される（安政の大獄）。
sen.e: Sanai was executed (Ansei no Taigoku).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Sanai was executed (Ansei no Taigoku).
Sanai was executed (Ansei no Taigoku).

sen.j: 井伊直弼は桜田門外の変で暗殺され、春嶽は文久2年（1862年）に幕政への参加を許される。
sen.e: Naosuke II was assassinated in the Sakuradamongai Incident and Shungaku was allowed to join the shogunate government in 1862.
Naosuke II was assassinated in the Sakuradamongai Incident and Shungaku was allowed to join the shogunate government in 1862.
Naosuke II was assassinated in the Sakuradamongai Incident and Shungaku was allowed to join the shogunate government in 1862.

sen.j: 朝廷では島津斉彬の死後、弟の島津久光が兵を率いて京都へ上洛し、政局に積極的に関わっていた。
sen.e: In the Imperial Court, after the death of Nariakira SHIMAZU, his younger brother Hisamitsu SHIMAZU went up to Kyoto with his solders and was actively involved in politics.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In the Imperial Court, after the death of Nariakira SHIMAZU, his younger brother Hisamitsu SHIMAZU went up to Kyoto with his solders and was actively involved in politics.
In the Imperial Court, after the death of Nariakira SHIMAZU, his younger brother Hisamitsu SHIMAZU went up to Kyoto with his solders and was actively involved in politics.

sen.j: 久光は勅使の大原重徳とともに江戸へ下り、慶喜将軍後見職就任や春嶽の政事総裁職就任を求める。
sen.e: Hisamitsu went down to Edo with an imperial envoy, Shigetomi OHARA to ask the bakufu to appoint Yoshinobu to Shogun-kokenshoku (one of three major posts of Edo bakufu) and Shungaku to the president of political affairs.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Hisamitsu went down to Edo with an imperial envoy, Shigetomi OHARA to ask the bakufu to appoint Yoshinobu to Shogun-kokenshoku (one of three major posts of Edo bakufu) and Shungaku to the president of political affairs.

Hisamitsu went down to Edo with an imperial envoy, Shigetomi OHARA to ask the bakufu to appoint Yoshinobu to Shogun-kokenshoku (one of three major posts of Edo bakufu) and Shungaku to the president of political affairs.

sen.j: 7月9日、春嶽は新設の政事総裁職に就任し、慶喜とともに京都守護職の設置、会津藩主松平容保の守護職就任、将軍の上洛など公武合体政策を推進する（→文久の改革）。
sen.e: On July 9, Shungaku was appointed to a new post, the president of political affairs and then pushed forward the policy of kobu-gattai (the union of the imperial Court and the Shogunate) with Yoshinobu such as establishing Kyoto shugoshoku (Military governor of Kyoto), appointing the lord of the Aizu Domain Katamori MATSUDAIRA to shugoshiki (military governor) and the shogun's going up to Kyoto (Bunkyu Reform).

On July 9, Shungaku was appointed to a new post, the president of political affairs and then pushed forward the policy of kobu-gattai (the union of the imperial Court and the Shogunate) with Yoshinobu such as establishing Kyoto shugoshoku (Military governor of Kyoto), appointing the lord of the Aizu Domain Katamori MATSUDAIRA to shugoshiki (military governor) and the shogun's going up to Kyoto (Bunkyu Reform).

On July 9, Shungaku was appointed to a new post, the president of political affairs and then pushed forward the policy of kobu-gattai (the union of the imperial Court and the Shogunate) with Yoshinobu such as establishing Kyoto shugoshoku (Military governor of Kyoto), appointing the lord of the Aizu Domain Katamori MATSUDAIRA to shugoshiki (military governor) and the shogun's going up to Kyoto (Bunkyu Reform).

sen.j: 春嶽は熊本藩出身の横井小楠を政治顧問に迎え、藩政改革や幕政改革にあたって彼の意見を重用した。
sen.e: Shungaku recruited Shonan YOKOI from the Kumamoto Domain as a political advisor and listened to his opinions on the reformation of domain duties and the shogunate political reform.
Shungaku recruited Shonan YOKOI from the Kumamoto Domain as a political advisor and listened to his opinions on the reformation of domain duties and the shogunate political reform.
Shungaku recruited Shonan YOKOI from the Kumamoto Domain as a political advisor and listened to his opinions on the reformation of domain duties and the shogunate political reform.

sen.j: 翌文久3年（1863年）には上洛するが、京都では長州藩など尊皇攘夷派が強く、慶喜が尊攘派と妥協しようとすると反対して3月2日に総裁職を辞任する。
sen.e: Although he went up to Kyoto in 1863, he resigned as the president of political affairs when Yoshinobu tried to make a compromise with Sonno Joi ha (supporters of the doctrine of restoring the emperor and expelling the barbarians) including the Choshu Domain, which had strong influence in Kyoto.

Although he went up to Kyoto in 1863, he resigned as the president of political affairs on March 2nd when Yoshinobu tried to make a compromise with Sonno Joi ha (supporters of the doctrine of restoring the emperor and expelling the barbarians) including the Choshu Domain, which had a strong influence in Kyoto.
sen.cmt: 3月2日が訳漏れのため、On March 2ndを追加しました。Aをstrongの前に追加しました。
sen.e: Although he went up to Kyoto in 1863, he resigned as the president of political affairs on March 2nd when Yoshinobu tried to make a compromise with Sonno Joi ha (supporters of the doctrine of restoring the emperor and expelling the barbarians) including the Choshu Domain, which had a strong influence in Kyoto.

sen.j: 会津藩と薩摩藩が協力した八月十八日の政変で長州藩が追放され、禁門の変で長州が失脚すると参預となる（→参預会議）。
sen.e: After the Choshu Domain was driven out of Kyoto in the Coup of August 18 for which the Aizu Domain and the Satsuma Domain worked together and fell from power in the Kinmon Incident, he became sanyo (councilor) (Council).

After the Choshu Domain was driven out of Kyoto in the Coup of August 18 for which the Aizu Domain and the Satsuma Domain worked together and fell from power in the Kinmon Incident, he became sanyo (councilor) (Council).

After the Choshu Domain was driven out of Kyoto in the Coup of August 18 for which the Aizu Domain and the Satsuma Domain worked together and fell from power in the Kinmon Incident, he became sanyo (councilor) (Council).

sen.j: 元治元年（1864年）2月15日には軍事総裁職に転じた容保に替わり京都守護職に就任し、翌日、越前守から大蔵大輔に転任する。
sen.e: Replacing Takamori who became the president of military affairs, he became Kyoto shugoshoku (Military governor of Kyoto) on February 15, 1864 and changed his post from Echizen no kami (Governor of Echizen Province) to Okura no taifu (a senior assistant minister of the Ministry of Treasury) the following day.
sen.cmt: 容保<http://www.ndl.go.jp/portrait/datas/334.html>軍事総裁職は直訳です
sen.e: Replacing Takamori, the general manager of military affairs then, he became Kyoto shugoshoku (Military governor of Kyoto) on February 15, 1864 and changed his post from Echizen no kami (Governor of Echizen Province) to Okura no taifu (a senior assistant minister of the Ministry of Treasury) the following day.
sen.cmt: takamoriの後にカンマを追加しました。who became the president of military affairs, をthe general manager of military affairs thenに変更しました。
sen.e: Replacing Takamori, the general manager of military affairs then, he became Kyoto shugoshoku (Military governor of Kyoto) on February 15, 1864 and changed his post from Echizen no kami (Governor of Echizen Province) to Okura no taifu (a senior assistant minister of the Ministry of Treasury) the following day.

sen.j: しかし、4月7日には京都守護職の任を免ぜられる。
sen.e: However, he was dismissed from the post of Kyoto shugoshoku on April 7.
However, he was dismissed from the post of Kyoto shugoshoku on April 7.
However, he was dismissed from the post of Kyoto shugoshoku on April 7.

sen.j: 慶応3年（1867年）には、島津久光や前土佐藩主の山内豊信（容堂）、宇和島藩主・伊達宗城らと四侯会議を開き、朝敵となった長州の処分について話し合い、春嶽は長州征伐には反対するが、2次に渡る長州征伐に至る。
sen.e: In 1867, he held the Shiko-kaigi (four major lords' meeting) with Hisamitsu SHIMAZU, the lord of the Tosa Domain Toyoshige YAMAUCHI, the lord of the Uwajima Domain Munenari DATE to discuss punishment on the Emperor's enemy, the Choshu Domain, which resulted in the twice Choshu conquest although Shungaku opposed it.

In 1867, he held the Shiko-kaigi (four major lords' meeting) with Hisamitsu SHIMAZU, Toyoshige YAMAUCHI, who was the former lord of the Tosa Domain, and Munenari DATE, who was the lord of the Uwajima DomainE to discuss punishment on the Emperor's enemy, the Choshu Domain, which resulted in the twice Choshu conquest although Shungaku opposed it.
sen.cmt: 四候が誰なのかわかりにくいため以下のように変更しました。, the lord of the Tosa Domain, Toyoshige YAMAUCHI, the lord of the Uwajima Domain, Munenari DATE→Toyoshige YAMAUCHI, who was the former lord of the Tosa Domain, and Munenari DATE, who was the lord of the Uwajima Domain
sen.e: In 1867, he held the Shiko-kaigi (four major lords' meeting) with Hisamitsu SHIMAZU, Toyoshige YAMAUCHI, who was the former lord of the Tosa Domain, and Munenari DATE, who was the lord of the Uwajima DomainE to discuss punishment on the Emperor's enemy, the Choshu Domain, which resulted in the twice Choshu conquest although Shungaku opposed it.

sen.j: 12月9日の王政復古 (日本)の宣言の前日、朝廷より議定に任命される。
sen.e: The day before the Restoration of Imperial Rule (of Japan) was declared on December 9, he was appointed to gijo (official post) by the Imperial Court.
The day before the Restoration of Imperial Rule (of Japan) was declared on December 9, he was appointed to gijo (official post) by the Imperial Court.
The day before the Restoration of Imperial Rule (of Japan) was declared on December 9, he was appointed to gijo (official post) by the Imperial Court.

sen.j: 王政復古後の薩摩藩、長州藩の討幕運動には賛成しなかった。
sen.e: After the Restoration of Imperial Rule, the Satsuma Domain and the Choshu Domain disagreed to the overthrow of the shogunate.
After the Restoration of Imperial Rule, the Satsuma Domain and the Choshu Domain disagreed to the overthrow of the shogunate.
After the Restoration of Imperial Rule, the Satsuma Domain and the Choshu Domain disagreed to the overthrow of the shogunate.

sen.j: 維新後、新政府では慶応4年（1868年）1月17日に内国事務総督、明治2年（1869年）5月15日民部官知事、同年7月8日民部卿、8月11日には大蔵卿を兼任。
sen.e: In the new government after the Meiji Restoration, he became the ministerial governor of Home Affairs on January 17, 1868, the governor of Popular Affairs on May 15, 1869, and Minbukyo (Minister of Popular Affairs) on July 8 of the same year, and served concurrently as Okura-kyo (Minister of the Treasury).

In the new government after the Meiji Restoration, he became the ministerial governor of Home Affairs on January 17, 1868, the governor of Popular Affairs on May 15, 1869, and Minbukyo (Minister of Popular Affairs) on July 8 of the same year, and served concurrently as Okura-kyo (Minister of the Treasury).

In the new government after the Meiji Restoration, he became the ministerial governor of Home Affairs on January 17, 1868, the governor of Popular Affairs on May 15, 1869, and Minbukyo (Minister of Popular Affairs) on July 8 of the same year, and served concurrently as Okura-kyo (Minister of the Treasury).

sen.j: 8月24日には大学別当・侍読に就任。
sen.e: He became Daigaku betto (equivalent to a president of university) and Jidoku (imperial tutor) on August 24.
He became Daigaku betto (equivalent to a president of university) and Jidoku (imperial tutor) on August 24.
He became Daigaku betto (equivalent to a president of university) and Jidoku (imperial tutor) on August 24.

sen.j: 同年9月26日に正二位に叙せられた。
sen.e: On September 26 of the same year, he received Shonii (Senior Second Rank).
On September 26 of the same year, he received Shonii (Senior Second Rank).
On September 26 of the same year, he received Shonii (Senior Second Rank).

sen.j: 明治3年（1870年）に政務を退く。
sen.e: He was retired from government affairs in 1870.
He was retired from government affairs in 1870.
He was retired from government affairs in 1870.

sen.j: 明治14年（1881年）勲二等旭日重光章受章。
sen.e: In 1881, he received the Order of the Rising Sun, Gold and Silver Star.
In 1881, he received the Order of the Rising Sun, Gold and Silver Star.
In 1881, he received the Order of the Rising Sun, Gold and Silver Star.

sen.j: 明治21年(1888年)に従一位に叙せられ、翌年勲一等旭日大綬章を受章。
sen.e: He received Juichii (Junior First Rank) in 1888 and Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun in the following year.
He received Juichii (Junior First Rank) in 1888 and Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun in the following year.
He received Juichii (Junior First Rank) in 1888 and Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun in the following year.

sen.j: 明治23年（1890年）に小石川の自邸で死去、享年64。
sen.e: In 1890, he died in his home in Koishikawa at the age of 64.
In 1890, he died in his home in Koishikawa at the age of 64.
In 1890, he died in his home in Koishikawa at the age of 64.

sen.j: 墓所は東京都品川区の補陀洛山海晏寺。
sen.e: His graveyard is in the Fudarakusan Kaian-ji Temple in Shinagawa Ward, Tokyo.
His grave is in the Fudarakusan Kaian-ji Temple in Shinagawa Ward, Tokyo.
sen.cmt: graveyard をgraveに変更しました。
sen.e: His grave is in the Fudarakusan Kaian-ji Temple in Shinagawa Ward, Tokyo.

sen.j: 死の翌年の明治24年（1891年）には佐佳枝廼社（越前東照宮）に春嶽の霊が合祀された。
sen.e: In 1891, a year after his death, the sprit of Shungaku was enshrined together in the Sakaeno-yashiro Shrine (Echizen Tosho-gu Shrine).
In 1891, a year after his death, the sprit of Shungaku was enshrined together in the Sakaeno-yashiro Shrine (Echizen Tosho-gu Shrine).
In 1891, a year after his death, the sprit of Shungaku was enshrined together in the Sakaeno-yashiro Shrine (Echizen Tosho-gu Shrine).

sen.j: 昭和18年（1943年）には春嶽を主祭神とする別格官幣社福井神社が創建された。
sen.e: The Fukui-jinja Shrine, the Bekkaku-Kanpeisha (a special government shrine), which enshrines Shungaku as a main deity was built in 1943.
The Fukui-jinja Shrine, the Bekkaku-Kanpeisha (a special government shrine), which enshrines Shungaku as a main deity, was built in 1943.
sen.cmt: deityの後にカンマを追加しました。
sen.e: The Fukui-jinja Shrine, the Bekkaku-Kanpeisha (a special government shrine), which enshrines Shungaku as a main deity, was built in 1943.

sen.j: 辞世の歌は、「なき数に よしや入るとも 天翔り 御代をまもらむ すめ國のため」。
sen.e: His death poem (composed on the eve of his death) is: "If I don't come back alive, I'll fly in the sky to save the imperial reign for our country".
His death poem (composed on the eve of his death) is: "If I don't come back alive, I'll fly in the sky to save the imperial reign for our country".

sen.j: 「明治」という年号は春嶽が命名したという
sen.e: The name of the era, "Meiji" was named by Shungaku.
